content:
It's like the preliminary puzzle to CodinDice.
Good idea, but now that CodinDice is here it would be nicer if the I/O were compatible.

Inputs can't be compatible because I have all faces oriented. 
Die in the other problem can "only" move on a plane 
while in my problem, we can see it as moving in space.
So I could use cardinals (WEST, NORTH, SOUTH, EAST), easy to understand.
But what about the two extra : TOP, BOTTOM ? Is the plane of the back face the reference ?

Also, he need only to track the position of the face (WEST, NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, TOP, BOTTOM) and I need to track it's orientation.

As an example, when he has a face "TOP", it can be "TOP NORTH", "TOP EAST", "TOP WEST" or 'TOP SOUTH" for me.

He deals with 6 states while I deal with the 24 states.

That's why the codification is very succinct.

TOP NORTH becomes "1U".

At the end, I find it easier to see the die floating in space and one twisting it around one of the 3 axis than having it rolling one some imaginary planes that are orthogonal.

I don't think it's that different.

Added complexity: track all faces instead of one. Mitigation: the tracking's the same anyway, just do it for all faces instead of a single one.
Faces are oriented conceptually, but that doesn't need to be tracked as such by the program.

Added complexity: spins (top/bottom face rotations). Mitigation option 1: they're not needed (that's my rough opinion). Mitigation option 2: express as spin instead of roll,


The other very similar puzzle that comes to mind is the 2x2x2 Rubik's cube moves one. Yours is quite literally a 1x1x1 Rubik's cube move analog. That notation is standardized as well, whether you use the UFRLDB series or the xyz one.

PS: it's not clear to me what you mean in your output format, expressing an orientation as a face.

Indeed, I did a mess :-D
I am now simplifying things & the Go program too. 
Only two faces need to be tracked.

Now the problem uses standard notation all the way!

It's also way simpler than the previous incarnation.

I like where this is going :)

Two things:
- standard xyz notation is in lowercase for some reason (as opposed to UFRBLD, who are correctly uppercase)
- the I/O is now a bit underspecified (it's considered bad form to require external web access to solve a problem). This involves:
  * what x/y/z actually mean as moves
  * the fact x' y' z', x2 y2 z2 exist
  * what UFRLBD actually mean as face positions
I updated it with your remarks.
Clarified the puzzle statement a bit and fixed the stub generator. Changed the title to be similar to the 2×2×2 version of the puzzle.
I thought I had one more correction to make, but it appears it's been solved while I solved again. Oh well. Approved.
